body_text.text: Our previous studies on keratoconus stroma showed that β-actin and HuR expression levels were downregulated at the mRNA and protein expression levels compared to normal stroma.
This raised the possibility that downregulation of HuR and β-actin could be a result of the interplay between the two [12].
In the present study, we used siRNA-mediated gene knockdown to determine if HuR gene silencing affects the stability of β-actin mRNA.
The decreased HuR expression resulted in decreased β-actin gene and protein expression leading to decreased fibroblast wound healing and their proliferation.
Human corneas: Normal corneas, stored in Optisol (Chiron Ophthalmics, Irvine, CA) at 4 °C, were obtained within 12 h after enucleation from the Alabama Eye Bank.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The central 8-mm region of the normal corneas was trephined and recovered.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The epithelium and the endothelium were scraped off, leaving the stroma to be used in these experiments.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The procurement of human corneas in this study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the University of Alabama at Birmingham, following the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki for Research Involving Human Subjects.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Cell culture and transfection: The stroma was incubated overnight in collagenase (1 mg/ml; Worthington, Lakewood, NJ).
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The resulting keratocytes were washed in Dulbecco's modified Eagles medium (DMEM; Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY) containing 1% antibiotics (penicillin-streptomycin solution, Mediatech, Herndon, VA).
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The primary cultures of human corneal fibroblasts were established [12], and the cells from passage 2 were used for this study.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The cells were then seeded onto six-well plates (Corning, Franklin Lakes, NJ) in DMEM containing 10% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone, Logan, UT) and 1% antibiotics (penicillin-streptomycin solution) at 37 °C in a 5% CO 2 .
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Four individual cell cultures were generated from four different donor corneas, and all experiments were performed using these cultures.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Gene knockdown studies: Knockdown of HuR or β-actin genes in normal human corneal fibroblasts was performed using siRNA duplexes.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The siRNA transfection was done on fibroblasts derived from four different corneas.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The cells were plated at 1.5×10 5 cells per well in a six-well plate and grown overnight at 37 °C with 5% CO 2 .
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The silencer select, predesigned, and validated siRNA sequences were purchased from Ambion (Life Technologies, Invitrogen, Cambridge, MA).
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The siRNA sequences that targeted the specific coding regions of GAPDH (used as a positive control), β-actin, or HuR were used.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: In addition, a nonspecific, scrambled siRNA duplex was used as a control to examine its effect of transfection, and it was denoted as siCTR.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: A dose-response curve established that the 5 nM concentration of siRNA gave an optimal response in transfected cells.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: We used a scrambled sequence and the GAPDH siRNA as the siRNA controls.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The siRNA sequences were diluted in OPTI-MEM1 reduced medium (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY) and transfected using Lipofectamine Plus (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) using the manufacturer's protocol.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The cells were processed at 24 h and 72 h after transfection to determine the expression of the targeted genes at the transcriptional and translational levels.
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The following siRNA duplex sequences were used: HuR (5ʹ-GCG UUU AUC CGG UUU GAC ATT UGU CAA ACC GGA UAA ACG CAA-3ʹ; β-actin (5ʹ-CCU GUA CAC UGA CUU GAG ATT UCU CAA GUC AGU GUA CAG GTA-3ʹ).
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: Proteins were recovered from cultured corneal fibroblasts after transfection and homogenization in radioimmunoprecipitation assay (RIPA) buffer (Thermo Scientific, Rockford, IL).
body_text.section: METHODS

body_text.text: The reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) analysis was performed using the Access RT-PCR system (Promega, Madison, WI), with 500 ng of RNA.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The primers were designed using Primer 3 for β-actin, HuR, and GAPDH are as follows: β-actin forward (5′-GTT GCT ATC CAG GCT GTG-3′); β-actin reverse (5′-TGA TCT TGA TCT TCA TTG TG-3′); HuR forward (5′-ATG AAG ACC ACA TGG CCG AAG ACT-3′); HuR reverse (5′-AGT TCA CAA AGC CAT AGC CCA AGC-3′); GAPDH forward (5′-GAG TCA ACG GAT TTG GTC GT-3′); GAPDH reverse (5′-TTG ATT TTG GAG GGA TCT CG-3′).
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The PCR products were analyzed using agarose gel electrophoresis.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Images were captured with a gel documentation system.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Four fibroblast cultures from four different normal corneas were used for gene silencing, and experiments were performed in triplicate.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Real-time PCR quantification was performed using the Bio-Rad iCycler iQ system (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA).
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) was performed using 96-well reaction plates in a total volume of 25 μl.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The reaction mixture included 12.5 μl of Real-Time SYBR Green PCR Master Mix (Bio-Rad), 2.5 μl of reverse transcription product, 1 μl of forward and reverse primers, and 8 μl of DNase/RNase free water.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The reaction mixtures were initially heated at 95 °C for 10 min to activate the polymerase, followed by 40 cycles, which consisted of the denaturation step at 95 °C for 15 s, annealing at 56 °C for 60 s, and the elongation step at 72 °C.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The data were normalized to 18S RNA.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The qRT-PCR data were analyzed with the comparative ∆Ct method.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Western blot analysis: Samples containing 30 μg protein were lysed with 1X sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) gel-loading buffer and analyzed with SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) using 12% polyacrylamide gels [13].
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Proteins were transferred to a polyvinylidene fluoride membrane (Bio-Rad) by using a semidry transfer cell (BioRad, Trans-blot SD), and blocked with 3% nonfat milk in PBS (1X; 137 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, 10 mM Na 2 HPO 4 , 2 mM KH 2 PO 4 , pH 7.4) for 1 h at room temperature.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The membranes were probed with anti-β-actin monoclonal antibody (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) at a 1:100 dilution, followed by incubation in goat anti-mouse secondary antibody conjugated to infrared fluorescent dye (IRD; LI-COR Biosciences, Lincoln, NE) at 1:10,000 dilution.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Blots were scanned using the Odyssey Imaging system (LI-COR Biosciences).
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: If reprobing of a blot was desired, the antigen-antibody complex was stripped using a mild stripping solution (0.2 M glycine-HCl, pH 2.2, 0.1% SDS, 0.01% Tween-20) for 1 h at room temperature, followed by 3X washing with PBS-0.1% Tween-20.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The membranes were then blocked as described and reprobed with anti-vimentin monoclonal antibody (Sigma) at 1:200 dilution, followed by incubation with the secondary antibody as described, and scanning using the Odyssey Imaging system.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The pixel intensity of the western blots, normalized to vimentin, was analyzed using Image-J software [14].
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The normalized value of siCTR was considered 100%, and the other values were calculated compared to the siCTR value.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The results are shown in a bar graph with standard deviations.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence-confocal Imaging: Normal corneal fibroblasts were seeded on 18-mm cover-glasses for 24 h, and then the cells were transfected as described in the Methods section.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: After 72 h, the cells were fixed with 4% formaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature, and washed three times with PBS.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The cells were permeabilized by incubation in 0.5% Triton X-100 in PBS for 10 min, followed by washing three times in PBS.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The cells were then incubated with a blocking solution containing 10% normal serum and 0.5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in PBS for 1 h, and incubated with the desired primary antibody at 4 °C for 24 h.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Next, the cells were washed three times in PBS, followed by incubation with a secondary antibody for 1 h in the dark.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: The cells were washed three times in PBS, and incubated with Hoechst nuclear stain for 10 min, washed again one time in PBS, and mounted on slides with a mounting medium (Fluromount-G, Southern Biotech, Birmingham, AL).
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Mouse immunoglobulin G (IgG) was used as a negative control with the identical protein concentration as that of the primary antibodies.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: Confocal imaging was performed using a Zeiss LSM 710 confocal microscope (Carl Zeiss Microscopy, Göttingen, Germany) at the High Resolution Imaging Facility of the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
body_text.section: Reverse transcription-PCR and real-time PCR analysis:

body_text.text: A modified Boyden chamber was used for the cell migration assay.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: We used a 96-well format ChemoTx system (Neuro Probe, Gaithersburg, MD), and the experiment was performed according to the manufacturer's protocol.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The siRNA transfection was performed with four different human corneal fibroblast cells.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: Fortyeight hours after transfection with the siRNA duplexes, the corneal fibroblasts were trypsinized, resuspended in serum-free medium, and seeded in the upper chamber of the Boyden chamber.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The reservoir of the chamber was filled with complete medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), and cells were allowed to migrate to the lower surface through a filter for 22 h at 37 °C.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The cells that remained in the top membrane surface were thoroughly wiped out using a moistened Kimwipe (Kimberly-Clark Global Sales, Roswell, GA).
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: Next, the membrane was cut out and inverted on a slide.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The cells that had migrated to the lower surface were stained using hematoxylin stain.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The siRNA treatment and the cell migration assay were performed in triplicate.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The migratory cell images were photographed using the Zeiss AxionPlan 2 Imaging System Microscope (Carl Zeiss Microscopy, Thornwood, NY) at the Core Facility of Vision Sciences Research Center of the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The cells were counted from six images, and the data are presented with standard deviations.
body_text.section: Cell migration assay:

body_text.text: The cells were plated at 1.5×10 5 cells per well of a 12-well plate and grown overnight at 37 °C with 5% CO 2 .
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: The siRNA transfection was performed on four different human corneal fibroblast cells.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: The 80% confluent cells were treated with siRNA as described, and after 72 h, a straight line scratch was made on a confluent monolayer of cells using a sterile 1 ml disposable serological pipette.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: To remove debris and smooth the edge of the scratch, the cells were washed with 1 ml DMEM.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: Images of the cell proliferation were taken using a Nikon Eclipse TS100 microscope (NiKon Eclipse TS 100 , Southern Micro Instruments, Marietta GA) at 0 h and 24 h after the scratch with a Nikon Coolpix camera attached to the microscope.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: The siRNA treatment and the scratch assay were performed in triplicate.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: The cells were counted manually at 0 h and after 24 h post-scratch from six images, and the data are presented with standard deviations.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: To observe the effects of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibition, the cells were treated with 10 µM LY 292,004 (Sigma) for 24 h after wounding.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: A p value of <0.05 was judged (±standard error of the mean [SEM]) to be statistically significant as determined by the Student t test.
body_text.section: Wound healing assay:

body_text.text: Our previous results showed downregulation in the expression of β-actin and HuR genes in keratoconus corneal stroma relative to normal corneas [12].
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: In the present study, we used RNAi-mediated gene silencing for β-actin or HuR in normal corneal fibroblasts to understand the respective gene functions.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: The GAPDH gene and scrambled sequence (which do not affect any targeted genes) were used as positive and negative controls for transfection, respectively.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: The sequences of the siRNA duplex were selected from the coding region of the desired target mRNAs, and the transfection was performed as described in the Methods section.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: The desired mRNA levels were analyzed using RT-PCR at 24 h post-transfection.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Figure 1A(I) shows β-actin gene expression using β-actin primers after transfection of human corneal fibroblasts with the scrambled siRNA, siGAPDH, siβ-actin, or siHuR.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Expression of the β-actin gene was downregulated after the HuR gene was silenced, which suggested that HuR has a regulatory role in β-actin gene expression.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Additionally, β-actin gene silencing also showed downregulation of the β-actin gene, which was used as the control.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Figure  1A(II) shows HuR gene expression using HuR primers after transfection of human corneal fibroblasts with siRNA for scrambled, GAPDH, β-actin, or HuR.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Expression of the HuR gene was downregulated on HuR gene silencing, whereas β-actin gene silencing had no effect on HuR expression.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Figure 1B shows western blot analysis of β-actin expression after transfection with the siRNA of scrambled, GAPDH, β-actin, and HuR.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: The western blot results show the reduced expression of β-actin and HuR relative to vimentin (used as the control).
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: For visualization of vimentin with anti-vimentin antibody, the blot that was used for β-actin visualization was stripped and used again for the vimentin visualization.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: RT-PCR analysis showed that after 24 h, GAPDH gene silencing had no effect, and the expression remained at the same level (data not shown), which was confirmed with the western blot analysis.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Figure 1C shows the percentage of β-actin expression levels after they normalized to vimentin and calculated as described in the Methods section.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Relative to the expression of vimentin, the levels of β-actin expression were 24% and 18% lower after HuR and β-actin gene silencing, respectively.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: This suggests that the loss of HuR results in downregulation of the β-actin gene.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: There was no change in the β-actin expression levels after the GAPDH gene or negative control (siCTR) was silenced.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Figure 1D shows the real-time PCR analysis after 72 h of siRNA treatments for the siCTR, GAPDH, HuR, and β-actin genes.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: The y-axis in the figure shows the relative fold expression, and the x-axis shows the β-actin primer used for the real-time PCR analysis.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: β-actin gene expression decreased by 80-90% after the β-actin and HuR genes were silenced, which was similar to the RT-PCR analysis.
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: Whereas GAPDH gene silencing suppressed β-actin gene expression after 72 h of gene silencing ( Figure 1D).
body_text.section: Human antigen R knockdown leads to a decrease in β-actin expression in stromal fibroblasts at transcriptional and translational levels:

body_text.text: To further verify the western blot results, we used confocal imaging to localize the individual proteins after siRNA treatment.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: We analyzed whether β-actin gene silencing affected HuR expression in corneal fibroblasts ( Figure 2).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 2 shows the immunoreactivity to the anti-HuR antibody of the corneal fibroblasts transfected with GAPDH siRNA, HuR siRNA, or β-actin siRNA.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: The effect on HuR gene expression was analyzed after the GAPDH gene was silenced.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 2A,D,G show Hoechst nuclear staining (blue fluorescent staining), and Figure 2B,E,H shows the immunoreactivity to the anti-HuR antibody.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Green fluorescent staining in the nuclear region (punctate in appearance) was observed on immunoreactivity with the anti-HuR antibody in the cells treated with siGAPDH ( Figure 2B), and with β-actin siRNA ( Figure 2E).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 2C,F,I is an overlay of Figure 2A,B,D,E,G,H.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: GAPDH gene silencing had no effect on HuR gene expression.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: β-actin gene silencing had no effect on the expression of HuR as represented by the presence of green fluorescent staining in the nuclear region ( Figure 2E).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: The effect of β-actin gene silencing on HuR expression was in concordance with our previously described RT-PCR and western blot results.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: In contrast, HuR gene silencing resulted in the loss of HuR expression, which representing a loss of green punctate fluorescent staining ( Figure 2H).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Together, the results show that HuR expression was downregulated in corneal fibroblasts after transfection with HuR siRNA ( Figure 2H), whereas β-actin and GAPDH gene silencing had no effect on HuR expression ( Figure 2B,E).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Next, we analyzed whether HuR gene silencing affects β-actin gene expression ( Figure 3).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 3 shows the immunoreactivity of corneal fibroblasts to the anti-β-actin antibody following transfection with GAPDH siRNA, HuR siRNA, or β-actin siRNA.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: F-actin was visualized by using rhodamine-labeled phalloidin (toxin from the mushroom Amanita phalloides).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 3A,E,I,M shows the Hoechst nuclear blue stain, and Figure 3B,F,J,N shows the immunoreactivity to the anti-β-actin antibody of the corneal fibroblasts after transfection with scrambled siRNA, siGAPDH, siHuR, or siβ-actin, respectively.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: The scrambled siRNA treatment showed no effect on β-actin expression as seen by the presence of uniform green fluorescent stain in cells with the anti-β-actin antibody ( Figure 3B).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 3C,G,K,O shows F-actin staining with rhodamine-labeled phalloidin (red fluorescence), following transfection with scrambled siRNA, siGAPDH, siHuR, or siβ-actin, respectively.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Figure 3D,H,L,P shows an overlay of Hoechst nuclear stain, immune-stain with anti-β-actin antibody, and F-actin staining after transfection.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Together, the results show that scrambled siRNA treatment had no effect on β-actin gene expression.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: On examination of the effects of GAPDH knockdown on β-actin expression ( Figure 3E-H), decreased levels of green fluorescence (due to β-actin [ Figure 3F]) and red fluorescence (due to F-actin [ Figure 3G]) were observed.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Together, the results showed that β-actin expression affected GAPDH gene silencing ( Figures 3F,G), whereas it remained unaffected with the use of scrambled siRNA.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: We analyzed the effect of HuR gene silencing on β-actin gene expression ( Figure 3I-K), which showed an absence of green fluorescence (due to β-actin, Figure 3J) and decreased red fluorescence (staining F-actin; Figure 3K).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: β-actin gene knockdown was used as a positive control to examine the effects of gene silencing.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Similarly, β-actin gene knockdown ( Figure 3M-P) resulted in an absence of green fluorescence (due to β-actin, Figure 3N) and decreased red fluorescence of F-actin (staining F-actin, Figure 3O).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Together, the results suggested that the silencing of HuR or β-actin gene ( Figure 3J,N) resulted in downregulation of the β-actin gene, as observed earlier during western blot analysis ( Figure 1B).
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Further, the HuR gene seems to be a stability factor for β-actin mRNA, and plays a role in gene expression.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: In contrast, the β-actin gene had no effect on HuR gene expression.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: However, the downregulation of the β-actin gene after gene silencing of GAPDH ( Figure 3F) was a surprise to us, and has been shown for the first time.
body_text.section: Localization of proteins after downregulation of their genes using immunohistochemical-confocal imaging:

body_text.text: Next we analyzed the functional significance of the loss of the HuR gene and whether it leads to a loss in the cytoskeletal function such as corneal fibroblast migration.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Cell migration is an important biologic process mainly generated by the β-actin cytoskeleton [3].
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: The modified Boyden chamber assay was used to determine if targeted deletion of the HuR or β-actin gene affected migration of normal corneal fibroblasts.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Figure 4A    Note that β-actin and HuR gene silencing affected β-actin expression.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Scrambled siRNA transfection of normal corneal fibroblasts showed no effect on β-actin expression, whereas GAPDH siRNA treatment had a drastic effect on β-actin expression.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: 4F) were counted using Image-J software, incorporating multiple images and standard deviation analysis.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Together, the results show that scrambled siRNA treatment had no effect on cell migration, which was identical to that of normal cell migration ( Figure 4A,B).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: GAPDH gene silencing resulted in reduced cell migration compared to the scrambled siRNA.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Silencing the HuR gene significantly decreased cell migration, whereas β-actin gene silencing abolished the migration.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Although it is known that β-actin is an essential component of cell migration [15], the role of HuR in cell migration is shown for the first time in this report.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on migration of normal corneal fibroblasts:

body_text.text: Next we analyzed whether HuR gene silencing affects the migration and proliferation of corneal fibroblasts.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: A normal corneal fibroblast cell layer, grown to 85% confluency, was transfected with scrambled siRNA and siRNA of GAPDH, β-actin, or HuR, and the non-transfected cells were used as a control.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: A scratch wound was created at 72 h after transfection, and the dotted line in Figure 5 shows the wounded area.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: The images were taken at 0 h and 24 h post-scratch using a phase contrast microscope with a Nikon camera ( Figure 5).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: The cells that migrated to the region between the dotted lines (wound) were counted from multiple images and the standard deviation determined ( Figure 5K).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Figure 5A,B shows the extent of the migration of the corneal fibroblasts at 0 h and 24 h postscratch, respectively.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Figure 5C-J shows the cell migration at 0 h and 24 h post-scratch following treatment with scrambled siRNA, GAPDH siRNA, HuR siRNA, or β-actin siRNA, respectively.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: The untreated normal corneal fibroblast layer had almost 100% wound closure in the region between the dotted lines ( Figure 5B) with similar results observed with scrambled siRNA ( Figure 5D).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: GAPDH siRNA treatment showed cell migration decreased after 24 h ( Figure 5F), but greater decreased migration was seen in the cells treated with HuR siRNA ( Figure 5H) or with β-actin siRNA ( Figure  5J).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Together, the results showed that the wound healing process was decreased after GAPDH gene silencing but a relatively greater decrease occurred with HuR and β-actin gene silencing.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Figure 5K summarizes cell migration at 24 h after wound healing subjected to different siRNA treatments.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Similarly, GAPDH siRNA treatment also resulted in decreased cell migration, GAPDH, an enzyme in the glycolytic pathway shown to have multiple functions, including an effect on cell motility during wound healing [16].
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: PI3K, is a known regulator of various cellular processes, including cell adhesion, vesicular trafficking, protein synthesis, cell growth, differentiation, cell survival, and cell transformation [17].
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: We performed a wound healing assay with Ly292004, a PI3K inhibitor, to examine how the inhibition of PI3K affects fibroblasts migration ( Figure 6).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Figure  6A,B,D,E,G,H shows cell migration at 0 h and 24 h postscratch following treatment with scrambled siRNA, β-actin  siRNA, or HuR siRNA, respectively.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Similarly, Figure 6C,F,I shows the results of PI3K inhibition using LY292004 after 24 h.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: After 24 h post-scratch, the untreated cells migrated to the wound ( Figure 6B) where on PI3K inhibition, severely impaired wound healing occurred ( Figure 6C).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: β-Actin and HuR gene silencing resulted in inhibition of wound healing after 24 h post-scratch as seen in Figure 6E,H, respectively.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: The inhibition of PI3K and gene silencing had the same effects as that of gene silencing alone ( Figure 6F,I).
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Figure  6J shows the downstream pathway of PI3K, and its inhibition would have a similar effect as that of β-actin and HuR gene silencing.
body_text.section: Effects of gene silencing on wound healing:

body_text.text: Our previous report showed that the expression levels of β-actin and HuR were downregulated in the human keratoconic corneal stroma but not in the normal corneal stroma [12].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In the present study, we used gene silencing to determine the functional properties of β-actin, and whether HuR gene silencing affects β-actin gene expression in cultured fibroblasts derived from the keratocytes of normal human corneas.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Gene silencing using RNA interference has been a popular method for in vitro gene functional studies using a method in which introducing dsRNA, homologous in sequence to the silenced gene, results in post-transcriptional gene silencing [18].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our RT-PCR analysis showed that gene silencing of β-actin or HuR for 24 h resulted in downregulation of β-actin gene expression.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The silencing of the HuR gene also resulted in downregulation of β-actin gene expression.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The levels of β-actin and HuR gene expression were reduced by 72% and 64% after β-actin and HuR gene silencing, respectively.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The mRNA of HuR is ubiquitously expressed in all proliferating cells, and it is the most important post-transcriptional regulator of gene expression [9].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: HuR binding to the U-rich element is involved in mRNA stability [5,11], and prolongs the half-life of β-actin mRNA [10].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Together, our present study showed that silencing the HuR gene resulted in downregulation of β-actin at the transcriptional and translational levels in corneal fibroblasts.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This downregulation could be due to the loss of HuR, a stability factor for β-actin mRNA.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: These expression levels were downregulated for up to 96 h post-siRNA treatment (results not shown).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In the present study, the immunohistochemicalconfocal imaging technique was used to localize proteins that were affected by gene silencing.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: When the HuR gene was silenced, its expression was decreased, but its expression was not affected after the GAPDH gene, the β-actin gene, or scrambled siRNA (data not shown) was silenced.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Gene silencing of either the HuR-or β-actin gene resulted in decreased expression of the β-actin gene.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Therefore, the HuR gene has a regulatory role in β-actin expression, which was confirmed at translational levels with confocal imaging.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Surprisingly, β-actin gene expression was also decreased after the GAPDH gene was silenced ( Figure 3F).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This could be due to diverse functions of GAPDH, such as DNA repair [19], tRNA export [20], and in cell death [21,22].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: GAPDH is also known to interact with tubulin and actin and thus plays a role in cytoskeleton dynamics [23].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Actin isoforms have highly conserved amino acid sequences.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Gama-actin expression was not affected when the β-actin gene was silenced in normal corneal fibroblasts (data not shown).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Cell culture studies have shown that β-and γ-actins have distinct physiologic roles.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In the motile cells, β-actin accumulates at the leading edge, and γ-actin tends to be at the stress fibers [24].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Complementing this was the finding that the β-actin mRNA was located at the leading edge of the moving fibroblast whereas γ-actin was localized at the stress fibers [25].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Recent studies using knockout mouse models have also shown that β-actin and γ-actins show distinct phenotypes.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This is further supported by the fact that in a β-actin knockout mouse, the embryonic fibroblasts showed a decreased G-actin pool compared to F-actin [15].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our results also showed positive F-actin staining in fibroblasts that showed the absence of β-actin staining in normal fibroblasts following β-actin gene silencing.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The presence of F-actin staining could be due to the presence of γ-actin in these cells.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This could also be due to the absence of the monomeric G-actin pool, which could lead to increased expression of megakaryoblastic leukemia (MAL also known as MKL) gene ID 89880, OMIM 60607; serum response factor (SRF) gene ID 6722 , OMIM 600589 (MAL-SRF) target genes.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Monomeric actins are known to inhibit coactivator MAL-SRF [26] and α-smooth muscle actin.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: One of the major functions of β-actin, but not that of γ-actin, is in cell motility [27].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Overexpression of the β-actin gene results in plasma membrane protrusions and cell migration [28].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our cell motility analysis using Boyden chambers showed that gene silencing of β-actin drastically reduced the cell migration ( Figure 4E).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Cell migration was also decreased when HuR was downregulated ( Figure 4D) but was unaffected in untreated cells or those treated with scrambled siRNA.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Cell motility is an important feature of multicellular organisms, maintained by actin-based protrusions such as lamellipodia, ruffles, and filopodia [29].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: We observed for the first time that GAPDH gene silencing also affected cell migration, possibly by way of its known function as an actinbinding protein.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: It has been recently reported that glycolytic enzymes, which included GAPDH, are associated with actin and other membrane proteins [30].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This association might satisfy the high ATP energy demand during actin dynamics.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Keratocytes repopulate the stroma at the site of an injury by a combination of proliferation and migration, which is stimulated by cytokines released from the epithelium [31].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This leads to a series of events that causes the keratocyte transformation to fibroblasts and myofibroblasts, and irregular spacing of collagen fibrils [32].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Silencing of the β-actin and HuR genes resulted in a significant decrease in wound healing as evidenced by the decrease in the cell migration in a scratch-wound gap in a confluent cell layer ( Figure 5H,J).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In contrast, complete wound healing occurred in normal corneal fibroblasts, and those treated with scrambled siRNA, whereas GAPDH siRNA also showed decreased cell migration.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Together, the results suggest the importance of β-actin and HuR in cell motility during wound healing.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The unexpected role of GAPDH in cell migration and proliferation requires further study.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The actin cytoskeleton is indispensable for wound repair, and PI3K is one of the key enzymes involved in this process [33].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Small G-protein, Rac1, which is an effector of PI3K, mediates stress-activated kinase c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), and is essential for basic fibroblastic growth factor ( bFGF)-induced fibroblast migration [33].
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: A specific inhibitor of PI3K, LY292004, causes significant inhibition of cell growth and migration.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our results also show inhibition of PI3K by LY292004 significantly inhibited cell growth and migration in siCTR cells ( Figure 6J).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This was similar to cells that had undergone β-actin or HuR gene silencing.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The absence of β-actin monomers (an effect of β-actin gene knockdown) hinders actin cytoskeleton polymerization and thus affects cell migration and proliferation.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This result was similar to that of inhibition of PI3K ( Figure 6J) and an upstream element in the pathway ( Figure 6J).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: In summary, our findings show that downregulation of the HuR gene significantly reduces β-actin gene expression, and affects the migration and proliferation of corneal fibroblasts.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: These results also confirm our earlier findings that downregulation of the β-actin gene in keratoconus corneal stromal keratocytes is due to downregulation of the HuR gene.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Our future work will explore the significance of downregulation of the β-actin and HuR genes in the progression of keratoconus disease.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION
